docs.lead_paragraph: Women who give birth to premature or low-weight infants should take it as a warning to keep an eye on their own health, researchers say. These and other complications during pregnancy appear to be signs that a woman is at a higher risk for vascular diseases and other conditions later in life, they report in a recent issue of The British Medical Journal.
docs.abstract: Drs Naveed Sattar and Ian A Greer of Glasgow Royal Infirmary University in Scotland, reporting in British Medical Journal, conclude that women who give birth to premature or low-weight infants need to be monitored for later health risks such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Women who give birth to premature or low-weight infants should take it as a warning to keep an eye on their own health, researchers say.    These and other complications during pregnancy appear to be signs that a woman is at a higher risk for...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like millions of Americans, Caroline Polk, a freelance editor in Washington, was left deeply unnerved by the Sept. 11 attacks. She could not sleep and felt tense and nervous all the time. Unable to calm herself, she decided to go for counseling, paying out of her own pocket. After four months, her anxiety had subsided, and she quit.

headline.main: After Treatment for Mental Illness, Fight for Insurance Often Follows

docs.abstract: Article on reluctance of health insurance providers to offer individual coverage, at least at low-cost 'preferred' rates, to people with history of mental conditions; notes some 16 million Americans, those who are self-employed or have lost jobs and group benefits, rely on individual plans; insurers say reluctance to cover those with mental illness is justified; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Like millions of Americans, Caroline Polk, a freelance editor in Washington, was left deeply unnerved by the Sept. 11 attacks.    She could not sleep and felt tense and nervous all the time. Unable to calm herself, she decided to go for counseling,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Are some people just born more anxious than others? It is not that simple, but a new study suggests that inheriting a shorter version of a single gene appears to predispose people to fear.
docs.abstract: Study by National Institute of Mental Health researchers Dr Ahmad R Hariri and Dr Daniel R Weinberger, reporting in Science, suggests that inheriting shorter version of gene SLC6A4 appears to predispose people to fear and that gene plays role in anxiety disorders; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Are some people just born more anxious than others?    It is not that simple, but a new study suggests that inheriting a shorter version of a single gene appears to predispose people to fear.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 21 million Americans are all too familiar with the pain of osteoarthritis, a leading cause of life-changing disability in this country. It is a chronic condition that can only become more common as the population grows older, since the incidence rises as much as tenfold as people age from 30 to 65. But by understanding its known causes and associated risk factors, much can be done to forestall the discomfort and limitations imposed by arthritis, as well as relieve the symptoms of already established joint disease.

headline.main: Arthritis: Your 'Reward' for Wear and Tear

docs.abstract: Jane Brody, in first of three Personal Health columns on arthritis, focuses on what causes osteoarthritis, who is at risk and how to reduce risks; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Nearly 21 million Americans are all too familiar with the pain of osteoarthritis, a leading cause of life-changing disability in this country. It is a chronic condition that can only become more common as the population grows older, since the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Changing physical education classes so that students spend more class time in motion can yield measurable improvements in fitness, a new study reports. The study, which appears in the August issue of The Journal of Adolescent Health, found that students became more fit after just eight weeks of a new exercise regimen in class. The lead author, Dr. Robert G. McMurray of the University of North Carolina, and his colleagues based their findings on an experiment conducted in four school systems in the state. The study was an offshoot of an earlier report in which the researchers found early stages of high blood pressure in the state's elementary school children.
docs.abstract: Study headed by University of North Carolina researcher Robert G McMurray, published in August issue of Journal of Adolescent Health, finds that increasing exercise regimen in physical education classes makes students more fit; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Changing physical education classes so that students spend more class time in motion can yield measurable improvements in fitness, a new study reports.    The study, which appears in the August issue of The Journal of Adolescent Health, found that...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Healing Conversations,'' by Nance Guilmartin, Jossey-Bass/Wiley, $18.95. What do you say to a friend who has just learned she has cancer? How do you ask a co-worker for help with a family problem? How do you tell employees that their jobs are being eliminated? What do you say to a child whose beloved pet is ill or dying, and asks, ''Will he be O.K.?''

headline.main: Answers to the Question 'What Do I Say When . . .'

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews two books: Healing Conversations by Nance Guilmartin and The Parent's Guide to Children's Congenital Heart Defects by Gerri Freid Kramer and Shari Maurer; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two new studies report that from an early age, the brains and heads of autistic children develop differently from those of other children. But researchers said it was unclear what, if anything, might be learned from the findings.
docs.abstract: Two studies by University of Washington School of Medicine researchers Dr Stephen R Dager and Dr Elizabeth H Aylward, reported in current issue of Neurology, find that, from early age, brains and heads of autistic children develop differently than those of other children; accompanying editorial says no one has ever demonstrated connection between brain size and brain function (M)
docs.snippet: Two new studies report that from an early age, the brains and heads of autistic children develop differently from those of other children.    But researchers said it was unclear what, if anything, might be learned from the findings.

docs.lead_paragraph: What a moment for an American to take over the world's largest family planning organization. ''We're completely at odds with Bush policy,'' said Dr. Steven W. Sinding, who becomes director general of the International Planned Parenthood Federation in London this month.
docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Steven W Sinding, who has been named director general of International Planned Parenthood Federation in London; Sinding, in interview, discusses issues of abortion, fight against spread of AIDS and family planning and holds women's reproductive health and choice worldwide have become enangled in domestic political debate; photo (M)
docs.snippet: What a moment for an American to take over the world's largest family planning organization.    ''We're completely at odds with Bush policy,'' said Dr. Steven W. Sinding, who becomes director general of the International Planned Parenthood Federation...

docs.lead_paragraph: The promise of many biotechnology drugs is that they are the body's own solutions. Human proteins like insulin and growth hormones, the same substances that the body uses every day, are made through genetic engineering and given to people who do not make enough of the proteins on their own. But an outbreak of serious illnesses linked to the anemia drug Eprex shows that some patients do not react to genetically engineered proteins as if they were natural. The patients react as if the protein were a germ, and their immune systems try to destroy it.

headline.main: Rebellious Bodies Dim the Glow of 'Natural' Biotech Drugs

docs.abstract: Article on adverse reaction among some patients to genetically engineered protein drugs; focuses on outbreak of serious immune response illnesses linked to anemia drug Eprex, made by Johnson & Johnson and sold only outside US; photo (M)
